Class Table

  • java.lang.Object
    • Table

  • public class Table
extends java.lang.Object
    Table is the class that allows the creation and editing of tables inside a database. A Table object is practically a series of Attribute (might also be referred to as "column") objects held inside an ArrayList of type Attribute and encapsulates the basic information needed for this purpose:
    • The table's name
    • The number of attributes that the table holds
    • The Attribute objects which contain the content the user inputs
    • An ArrayList of the Tables constructed by the user.

    The class is designed in such manner that it will support methods inside of it and other classes externally to execute the usual functions that a database has, such as:

    • View Table's content
    • View a column's content
    • Input data into a table
    • Copy an entry to another position of the same or another table
    • Move an entry to another position of the same or another table
    • Copy a single field to another position of the same or another table
    • Move a single field to another position of the same or another table
    • Delete an entry
    • Delete a table
    • Erase a field
    • Substitute a field
    • Substitute an entry
    • More

    An important point to consider is that the methods inside the class are written in such a manner that they require the data input given in a strict way by the user.

    Author:
    George Bakalis, Andreas Vlachos

    • Constructor Detail

      • Table

        public Table(java.lang.String name)
        A simple constructor that only expects a name to initialize a table
        Parameters:
        name - the name to be used as a title for the table

    • Method Detail

      • checkType

        public boolean checkType(java.lang.String[] entries,
                         boolean correctEntry)
        This method implements a simple check on the entry that the user has given on demand, in order to decide if it has the correct number and types of input. It uses existing and custom exceptions to guide the user into a correct entry, if needed. If the user does not want to insert an element to a column he should type -- instead
        Parameters:
        entries - an array of String elements, which is the user's input
        correctEntry - a boolean initialized as true, prone to switching to false if there's a wrong input
        Returns:
        true if no mistake was found; false if there's a wrong input.

      • newEntry

        public void newEntry()
        This method creates an entry on the user's demand. It asks for the entry, splits it on commas and holds it inside an array. Checks whether the input is valid using checktype(String[], boolean) and then proceeds to pass the correct input inside the table.

      • getThisTable

        public java.util.ArrayList<Attribute> getThisTable()

        public int getAttributeNumber()

        public static Table getTables(int i)

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String name)

      • checkInput

        public boolean checkInput(int choice,
                          boolean correctEntry)
        This method implements a simple check on the entry that the user has given on demand, in order to decide if it is an integer between 1 and 6, as the choices indicate. It uses a custom exception to guide the user into a correct entry, if needed.
        Parameters:
        choice - int containing the user's choice
        correctEntry - a boolean initialized as true, prone to switching to false if there's a wrong input
        Returns:
        true if no mistake was found; false if there's a wrong input.

      • newAttribute

        public void newAttribute()
                  throws java.util.InputMismatchException
        This method creates an attribute (column) on the user's demand. It asks for a name and a data type for the attribute, checks for possible InputMismatchException and/or an invalid int via the checkInput(int, boolean) method. If everything is correct, a new Attribute object is successfully being initialized.
        Throws:
        java.util.InputMismatchException
